text.head:
Order
17/02/2022
text.p:
1.
By way of the present writ petition, the petitioner has prayed
thus:-
"A. By an appropriate writ, order or direction, the
respondents may kindly be directed to return the
original title deeds in respect of the properties
belonging to the petitioner which were given as
security by way of deposit of title deeds in respect of
the transaction covered by sanctioning letter dated
18.04.2015.
B. By an appropriate writ, order or direction, the
respondent may further be directed to return the
original title deeds of the properties stated below:-
a. Commercial office No.514, 515 & 516
admeasuring approx. 570 Sq. ft. situated at 3 rd
floor, SM Lodha Complex, Plot No.109-C. Shastri
Circle Post Office, Near Court Chauraha, Udaipur,
Rajasthan;
b. Commercial office No.513 admeasuring 165
Sq. ft. situated at 3 rd floor, SM Lodha Complex,
Plot No.109-C. Shastri Circle Post Office, Near
Court Chauraha, Udaipur, Rajasthan;
c. Commercial office No.512 admeasuring 305
Sq. ft. situated at 3 rd floor, SM Lodha Complex,
Plot No.109-C. Shastri Circle Post Office, Near
Court Chauraha, Udaipur, Rajasthan.
C. By an appropriate writ, order or direction the
response of the respondent bank Dt. 28.10.2021
whereby they have denied releasing the mortgaged
property, may kindly be castigated and appropriate
directions be issued to act in fair and lawful manner."

2.
Undisputed facts, which emanate from the record are that
the borrower M/s. Marudhar Metals and Minerals availed a credit
facility from the respondent -Bank of Baroda, in which the
present petitioner (Ashok Kumar Mehta) stood guarantor and
created security interest of his four properties.

3.
The borrower, however failed to honor its commitment, due
to which the respondent-Bank initiated proceedings under the
Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and
Enforcement of Security Interest (SARFAESI) Act, 2002
(hereinafter referred to as "the Act of 2002") and a notice under
section 13(2) of the Act was issued, whereafter the possession of
the secured assets were taken and after issuance of notice of
possession under section 13(4) of the Act of 2002, a notification
for e-auction notice was issued. Accordingly, e-auction was held
on 07.06.2019.

4.
In the e-auction aforesaid, all the four properties of the
guarantor were offered for sale. Scanned copy of the e-auction
notice is placed hereinfra:-
successful bidder and sale letter/communication for the same was
issued.

6.
In the meantime, the petitioner, guarantor for the loan
managed to deposit the entire outstanding amount with the
respondent-Bank. Out of which, a part payment was made prior
to the auction and remaining amount was paid after the auction
proceedings were held, however, before the sale letter got
registered.

7.
The petitioner has challenged the confirmation of sale of the
1 st property made in favour of the successful bidder before the
Debt Recovery Appellate Tribunal (hereinafter referred to as "the
Appellate Tribunal") and the matter is still pending consideration.

8.
The lis pending before the Appellate Tribunal is mainly for
consideration on the issue -"as to whether the authorized officer
was justified in confirming the sale in favour of successful bidder".

9.
The petitioner made a representation before the respondent-
Bank to release the original documents of his other three
properties, which are not subject matter of any dispute, as the
entire loan amount has been paid by the petitioner and there is no
dispute so far as the remaining three properties (property No.2, 3
and 4) are concerned.

10. The respondent-Bank turned down petitioner's request,
inter-alia, observing that the matter is pending before the
Appellate Tribunal and according to the terms and condition of the
loan, petitioner's remaining properties cannot be released.

11. Mr. Abhishek Pareek, learned counsel for the petitioner
argued that indisputably, the entire outstanding amount of the
respondent-Bank in relation to the credit facility availed by the
borrower has been paid and rather the petitioner has deposited an
excess amount of more than Rs. 10 lacs.

12. Learned counsel further argued that even if the petitioner's
appeal, pending before the Debt Recovery Appellate Tribunal, is
rejected or allowed, the sale would be either finalised in favour of
the auction purchaser or set aside. In either of the eventualities
respondent-Bank would not be requiring any further amount.
Hence, the respondent-Bank's action of not releasing documents
qua property No.2, 3 & 4 is arbitrary.

13. Mr. Dhanesh Saraswat, learned counsel appearing for the
respondent-Bank, on the other hand, submitted that as per the
loan agreement, unless the entire loan is cleared and 'No
Objection Certificate (NOC)' is issued in this regard, neither the
security interest created against the assets of the borrower or the
guarantor can be eschewed, nor can the documents be released.

14. Learned counsel for the respondent-Bank argued that the
petitioner should pursue his appeal before the Appellate Authority
and get the matter finally adjudicated. Whereafter, the Bank
would naturally release the original documents in accordance with
law.

15. It was also argued that in the representation/letter sent by
the petitioner, no extraordinary circumstances were pointed out
by the petitioner, under which the Bank should accede to his
request of releasing the documents.

16. An objection was also raised by learned counsel for the
respondent-Bank that the petitioner -a guarantor has approached
this Court, without impleading the borrower as party. Hence, the
writ petition is not competent.

17. Mr. Saraswat nevertheless submitted that as per the
instructions available to him, no excess amount has been
deposited by the petitioner.

18. Heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the
material available on record.

19. It is undisputed fact that the entire loan amount or the
amount advanced to the borrower M/s. Marudhar Metals and
Minerals stands paid by the borrower/guarantor.

20. The dispute, which is pending consideration before the
Appellate Tribunal is that, as to whether auction sale of property
No.1 made in favour of the successful bidder was valid or not.

21. In the opinion of this Court, in any eventuality, if the
petitioner's appeal succeeds or fails, the respondent-Bank is
having the original documents of title qua property No.1 and,
therefore, the contingency arising out of petitioner's appeal being
dismissed would be taken care of by the excess amount paid by
the petitioner.

22. Concededly, there is no quarrel in relation to remaining three
properties. The respondent-Bank's stand that unless the entire
dispute is resolved and NOC is issued in this regard, by the
respondent-Bank, it cannot handover the documents to the
petitioner, cannot be countenanced.

23. This Court does not find any substance in the respondent-
Bank's stance that the petitioner has not stated any specific
circumstance for which, the documents in question should be
released.

24. According to this Court, stand of the respondent-Bank per-se
is contradictory.

25. If the stand of the respondent-Bank is, that it cannot release
the documents unless NOC is granted then, it is inconsequential
whether reasons have been assigned or not by the petitioner. In
case their such stand does not find favour, then, they cannot sit
over the documents simply because the petitioner has failed to
give good reasons, why he requires the documents.

26. In the opinion of this Court, the petitioner is not required to
satisfy the respondent-Bank, as to why he is in requirement of the
document of other three properties.

27. The mere fact that the entire loan amount has been paid is
reason enough for a borrower/guarantor to ask for the documents.

28. In order to meet with the contingency, in case petitioner's
appeal before the Debt Recovery Appellate Tribunal fails (though
according to the petitioner excess amount is lying with the
respondent Bank) the petitioner may be called upon to file an
undertaking to pay the remaining amount (if any).
29. The writ petition is allowed.

30. The petitioner shall be required to file an undertaking before
the respondent-Bank that in case any further liability arises on
account of the dispute being pending before the Appellate
Tribunal, he shall pay the same to the respondent-Bank in
accordance with law, however, subject to his right of raising just
objection and challenging the same.

31. The respondent-Bank is directed to handover the original
documents to the petitioner of property No.2, 3 and 4 (excluding
the property No.1) within a period of one week of furnishing duly
notarised undertaking alongwith affidavit of petitioner.

32. In case, the petitioner fails to honor his undertaking, the
respondent-Bank shall be free to take up appropriate proceedings,
including filing of contempt petition.

33. The writ petition as well as stay application stands disposed
of.

(DINESH MEHTA),J
15-Ramesh/-
